caRCCoW6XuhhG0iFD1V6fw.text: For starters, you simply must walk down the alley from Lawnmarket so that you can enjoy the incredible view of The Scott Monument.   My traveling companion and I stopped in for a drink and dinner (what Americans would call "late lunch").  The decor is splendid and we felt a bit naughty walking in wearing tennis shoes and carrying bags of souvenirs, but we were quickly and enthusiastically seated upstairs.  I had the beet and tomato puree (soup) and finally warmed up after and afternoon of wandering around in "warm, sunny, Scotland."    I had the lamb burger-cooked to perfection with an excellent flavor profile of goat cheese, beet root, and middle Eastern spices.  My companion had the roast beef salad-tender juicy chunks of med rare roast beef doused with olive oil on a fresh bed of sophisticated greens with a sprinkling of sharp cheese.   Unlike other diners, we stuck with beer, bit wet did try the desserts.  Save room-I had the lemon and my companion had the chocolaty mousse and we BOTH contemplated living the bowl!   We left by 5pm, but I would return for an excellent evening!

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Main bar at The Devil&#39;s Advocate

4sEBgoj2t6vYUp7sXSlzqg.text: We had the chicken with olives,  tomatoes, potatoes and onion,  pork with apple and a ribeye steak with thick cut potatoes.  All were delicious.

N7jhBAfnbInMwPSds3DJNQ.text: The food is delicious. The people are friendly and the service was great. My group ended up ordering 4 entrees and a few sides and they were all delicious. The potatoes I had were perfection and my chicken was cooked perfectly and yet still very juicy. Loved it all:) Can't wait to go back, hopefully soon.

ipNActiMikJiNzRa-wLMRg.text: After a week of dismal eating experience in London we were hopeful for better options in Scotland.  Devils Advocate did not disappoint. We tried the chicken with cream peas and the beef with chimmichuri.  Both excellent!  I would highly recommend.

8YGOBDWVi_UWeRCzpizH9g.text: Not that this place needed any more positive reviews, but we had an amazing meal here. Did not feel rushed either.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

v6RvSE4VGDWCxkMi-uan-A.text: The food was amazing -- one of the better meals I ate in Scotland. The restaurant itself... not so much. We made a reservation (essential!) and went for dinner on a Friday night, and loved the food, but not much else.  Setting:3 stars. Really cool space, but they were blaring rap music so loudly that I could barely hear anyone speaking. People walking in seemed rather baffled as well -- it was just weird for the setting. Also, FULL of hen parties on a Friday night.  Service: 2 stars. When we went to ask about our reservation, we were told we were early (we were there 5 minutes early) and we should not have asked until it was exactly time. The hostess told us not to ask again, but to go wait, and she would find us. She was rude and brusque, but I figured it was late, loud, and she was tired. But then, she never bothered to get us. We watched her chat with friends for 20 minutes and pointedly ignore us... finally, we got frustrated and went upstairs, where the waiter was like "oh, there you are, we've had your table ready, what were you doing???" Ok then. Once we were seated our waitress was helpful enough, but when we got the bill she manually zeroed out the tip line. I wasn't sure if that was because she wanted to force us to give her a cash tip, or didn't want any tip... but I was confused. Maybe it's a cultural thing?  Food: So this is the redeeming part. I had the burger, and my husband had the ribeye. Both were cooked perfectly, and they were amazing. We'd had a lot of lack luster food, so this was a pleasant surprise. Both entrees were quite salty, but it worked. 5 stars.  TLDR: sure, stop by if they aren't busy, but not my scene on a Friday night. Loud, rude staff, but good food.

rbl9mF8XwHuGmLT0lyiE-Q.text: Hip space with a cozy atmosphere upstairs. I had the chicken and black pudding entree, and it was very tasty, and the chicken was juicy. We had a ham, cheese, and bread starter that I thought was a bit plain for the price. It would have been nicer if it maybe had two cheeses and a dab of relish!

3HaSNjQQHVqhcvf7cFKFIA.text: Such a shame, the venue itself is gorgeous and the menu looked promising but the service was gratuitously rude. We turned up for lunch on New Year's Eve and politely asked, as we sat down, if we could have some water - only to have the waitress/manager (dark hair, red dress/top, permanent scowl)  snap at us: 'That comes automatically.'.  Well it didn't come automatically, even though there was another waiter standing 4 feet away who heard us but then walked off (the place was pretty empty and we were the only ones in our section at that point). My lunch companion needed to take her medication so I got up and grabbed one of the water jugs he had been standing right next to; when he eventually returned and saw that we had done this, we got another waft of attitude from him.  The food: ordered the corn fritters and monkfish scampi; the fritters tasted bhaji-esque, and not in a good way  - sort of oily and muddy and mushy - and the fish was pretty forgettable ( all they'd done with the accompanying cauliflower and parsnips was boil and salt them and plonk them in a bowl without bothering to properly drain it all). It's even more disappointing given the fantastic, unfailingly friendly and helpful service and hospitality we experienced everywhere else off the Royal Mile that week.

VZdr-Cp5C1XbZaRYmml1pA.text: Impressed! Although it's tucked round a corner hidden from sight, if you're "in the know" this place is a hidden gem. Decorated tastefully in keeping with the age of the building. All wood and mismatched chairs and tables, the place has a very cool vibe about it.   We had a very warm welcome upon entering the bar. It wasn't busy but there was a few people dotted around. Clearly these people have heard of the new bar on the grapevine as I can't see how it'll ever get any passing trade tucked away as it is although there is a hotel next door. We were greeted by the bar staff and shown to a table upstairs. They only started serving food from Sunday so only had a small menu on offer. No mind! The steak and pork burger for me and the steak sandwich for my partner. What I liked about it was their "no problem" attitude when I changed my dish, swapping blue cheese for cheddar and removing the black pudding. I felt the food options were slightly over complicated and fussy however I can see what they're trying to do which is take simple dishes of burger, macaroni, haggis etc up a level.  Although neither of us were drinking I checked out the small cocktail menu and wine list. Looked interesting and quite reasonable. They made 2 lovely bramble and apple virgin cocktails for us so we could get a small flavour of what the bar staff could do. Yum!! The waiter serving us was extremely friendly and likable.   I'd like to come back at a time when I'm not driving and when their food menu is a little more extensive. If they can match the same quality of service at a busier time they'll definitely get 5 stars!! And you guys know how tights I am with my stars. Haha :)

4sZP6I8mKZ5st9X0EVeLUQ.text: Ambiance is local and professional. Food is unique and well thought through. Service was attentive and delightful. Wine list is awesome - All round top marks!

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

YvQEsYzMcBg-ucG5ZEbcSA.text: YELP 3RD BIRTHDAY PARTY!! woooooo!!  Ive been to The Devil's Advocate before, and its fast becoming a firm favourite for a number of reasons.  Firstly location; for me being a two minute walk to the the train station is a big positve for this train spotter. Secondly the staff and service is second to none! polite and attentive. Thirdly great ambience, including lighting, atmosphere and fun! Lastly food and drink is very good.  So...I was chuffed to hear Yelp was having their 3rd birthday there! We were all given a little party bag of goodies, our glasses were filled with a drink of our choice and my goodness cake..lots of cake ! and what can i say about the cake?!?! Delicious! Light and fruity!  Thank you for a fabulous evening full of yelp goodness ! Happy Birthday ! xx

fmrBMIDWj6iu2x7irDxjEA.text: We had gotten into town during a rather late dinner period, and were taking our chances on finding a spot to eat by walking around. We came across Advocate's Close and decided to walk through and see what was on the other side. We ended up finding this place and decided to go inside and see if they had a table available. They did, and this was one of the best meals I have enjoyed in quite a while. I had a meat pie with braised oxen cheeks and marrow. Delicious. The atmosphere is fantastic. It is a little dark on the inside but comfortable and cozy. Highly recommended.

dLDdquyNRtDswA8w1TJP6g.text: edinburgh is a wonderful city which is absolutely chock full of excellent bars and restaurants, but part of me (a small part) always felt that something was missing.  i didn't know what or why i even thought that, but on a cold wintry thursday evening i came across the 'something missing' in Devil's Advocate.  being asked to suggest a good place to go for some dinner and drinks, i immediately suggested this new bar in old town.  i'd had its praises sung to be by those that had been and i thought it was time i tried it out.  now i won't lie, finding this place isn't exactly easy.  i actually had a fall out with my taxi driver about the location of Advocate's Close.  thankfully i convinced him to drop me off nearby enough that i was soon skipping down the steps to find the bar.  there was a lot of steps....and i thought maybe i'd got the address wrong, but then just as i was giving up hope a beacon of light (and well mixed cocktails) appeared to my left and i entered through the glass doors.  i was immediately in love with this place.  The Devil's Advocate is all glass, brick, and cool industrial chic.  the building has massive glass windows looking out onto the close which must bring in loads of sunlight during the day.  in between all this glass is exposed brick and clean wooden tables with a mezzaine for with tables for the restaurant.  on arrival i had a g&t at the bar before we headed upstairs for dinner.  the menu is short and sweet, which i hopes means that they focus on what they're good at.  not a load of veggie options if you are one of those, but a good choice of other options overall.  i went with the salmon tartare for my starter and the pearl barley and beetroot risotto for my main.  my dining partner had the haggis crouquettes (or bon bons i can't remember) for starter and a steak sandwich for the main.  we split a bottle of sauvignon blanc as well.    the wine was with us shortly and was quite nice!  a wee bit pricey, but nothing i wouldn't expect of an edinburgh restaurant.  starters arrived not too long after and my salmon tartare was just lovely!  so so fresh and the slices of crostini with it were so crisp.  i would have enjoyed a bit more of the sauce on the plate, but hardly need to complain as the salmon itself was so tasty.  i was assured that the haggis was also quite good, but passed on the option to try it as i'm not a fan of the offal.  after a top up of the wine, mains arrived and i was well pleased with my risotto.  the pearl barely was super tasty and the beetroot was of the golden variety instead of the red that annoyingly stains everything.  the steak sandwich appeared to be quite satisfactory and i can assure you that the chips were also good having been given one to taste.  in leiu of dessert we went for some cocktails off their list.  if i'd been clever i would have written the names of these down as by that point we'd finished off the wine.... however, my whisky cocktail was certainly top quality and sort of had a tea like flavour.  like a long island iced tea except with whisky, so much classier.  my dining companion had a gin based cocktail that was seriously strong but also seriously good.  in addition to the good food and excellent cocktails, the staff at the Devil's Advocate are just lovely!  quite to serve you and helpful with questions about the menus, checking on you during your meal but not being overly obtrusive so you can also enjoy your meal.  they also seem happy to let people sit as we were there for almost 4 hours, and never once got asked for our table back.  seriously, i think i'm a little in love with this place.  it's just the sort of place the edinburgh was missing and just the sort of place i know i'll want to go back to over and over again!  already planning my next visit....

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

LBE0i8YtfvSgFyLZDPbxnw.text: Ohhh the ambience seeps through the old brick and timber!  I do love the feel of this place.  Is it the lighting?    I gathered here with a few others to celevrate the 3rd birthday of Yelp edinburgh.  The company was lovely and the drinks were a flowing (lovely prosecco btw).  I'm defo coming back to try the pulled pork on the menu and maybe evrything else!! it all sounds delish!

MaoemCEDJPIhKJu9Q7ZYlA.text: My second visit to this little gem confirmed my first impression of this place - it is ab fab!  After only having drinks the first time, this time we also had dinner which was lovely; hearty haggis bon bons, a luxurious truffle mac n' cheese, followed by a warming cullen skink pie and goat cheese, leek and pumpkin tart. Washed down with an excellent Chilean Pinot Noir. Perfect for a chilled Friday night meal!  The staff were outstanding; friendly and attentive.   As an avid fan of The Bon Vivant, their new venture DA is an absolute must to visit in Edinburgh.

jXi5h_xQIlq3jhAdMyIzBQ.text: Traveled all over Europe and decided this has been the best meal thus far. Absolutely amazing. 300+ whiskies! Get a reservation because everyone knows this is the place to go. Well done.

IECFrTXX12gNdhuOuviHOw.text: Now, I love The Bon Vivant with it's fab food and wine list and I'm way too much of a regular at The Bon Vivants Companion too so I was waiting with bated breath to see how The Devil's Advocate would turn out!  Well it is fab - love the bare walls, the excellent use of space, the cosy, under the mezzaine booths and the lovely ladies toilets. Full, amazing range of wine's and spirits as you'd expect and staff here also provide the same attention to detail touches on service that you come to expect as a regular to TBV.   I was here for the wines and spirits tasting - boozy as you'd expect, but it was great to grab a booth and chill out with plenty of water being provided to help balance the tastings we'd already indulged in, and were to still indulge in. Food menu is smaller than TBV so the Devil's Advocate will clearly focus more on drinks, but on some nights out, that won't be a bad thing!  So, I'll definitely be back - I just need to decide what I fancy drinking next!

R5XKpwN9GLUX5qwDlP-YwA.text: We didn't have a booking but we're seated for dinner with no problem.  Food and ambiance were great - I'd definitely come back here.

SwZ85Fo0VXtHDKKv-g5N1g.text: - Excellent food - Friendly but also professional and efficient staff - Nice though noisy ambiance

xOoVgcYSQnADzhhcWfGZ1g.text: Tiny. Exclusive cocktails. A carefully curated menu. Wood panelling and a bar to sell your soul to Lucifer for. And a beer garden. And tucked away from the crowds of the Royal Mile, but only seconds from everywhere in the Old Town. It probably doesn't get better than this.

EjVT9GMbv0InQwOJOAEj0w.text: If you like an aromatic cocktail, you cannot go wrong with the BV Sazerac - old school delicious.  Food was very good and we'll be back!

nW1aXR9YCMxtoSJ7DpPKvg.text: Loved this place! Down a beautiful cobbled Lane lies the delightful devils advocate! I opted for a tasty 'green hill' cocktail and the corn fed chicken. The chicken was cooked perfectly and had a delightful mushroom jus but the star of the show was the black pudding croquette...I would go back just for that! I had the chocolate mousse for dessert, this was a little heavier than expected but I still finished the lot! We sat outside with a liqueur before we left and noticed blankets were at each table incase customers got cold, what a nice touch! Would definitely recommend.

uJoLPj9af1bxBbJnmejasQ.text: In hindsight I should have connected the name of this bar with the address on my event invite with the name plate on the close it resides in. They all contain the easy to remember work 'Advocate' after all. Despite this geography-by-numbers approach to getting around town it still took me a while to find the place, so please do allow extra time if you're me.  Once inside it's really nice. Big doors, high tables, steep steps, distant ceilings: they've achieved a TARDIS-like effect with much going on inside a relatively small premises. Three stars gives them room for improvement, though in truth I suspect my general level of energy was a limiting factor to the good time I had here. It was still good though and clearly a place worth knowing about with its central location in no way compromised by the adjacent madding crowds. Please go.

yrIo8zAGvUUuslOiJTURww.text: I had the pleasure of attending this pub for the first time for Yelp's 3rd Birthday cake and wine event. A lovely crisp white was handed to me upon entry by a very nicely moustachioed man and then some amazing cake was gobbled up. The upstairs wouldmake a great events space, and the downstairs booths would make a nice intimate meal location. The food menu looks tip top as well.   I really like the feel of the Devil's Advocate, it's got some decent beers on tap which I shall be back to sample again and the environment felt pretty relaxed and enjoyable.   Will definitely be back to try out the food and everything else!

8y3V8vQ6Wlq_hNeBBFxhOA.text: We just stopped for drinks mid afternoon and loooved this place.  We had tried to come the night before (a Wednesday) and it was booked up!  So we stopped in for scotch and a cocktail as a break from an unseasonably warm day! Loved the shaded patio for cocktails.

cYSWsZJ7H4S7UulcNtZdtw.text: We were in Edinburgh for a weekend trip and after having dinner we asked the manager to recommend a good bar nearby.  We were looking for a place that wasn't touristy and had a good selection of whiskeys.  The manager recommended The Devil's Advocate which is located down the stairs of the Advocate's Close off of the Royal Mile.  We walked into the bar and instantly fell in love.  The decor is simple, cozy and well done.  Everyone was friendly and once we found our spot for the evening we got comfortable.  Our server was very knowledgeable and helped us through a mini whiskey tasting.  The great thing is that he charged us for tasting pours and not for full glasses which I thought was very honest of him.  He could've easily taken advantage of us being tourists.  After trying seven different whiskeys our bill came out to 29.65 GBP.   We loved the bar so much we went back the next day for lunch.  To our surprise the bar looked even more welcoming in the daytime. We ordered four drinks, one appetizer (had to try the haggis bonbons) and three entrees. Our bill came out to 51.30 GBP for three people.  Everything we ordered was delicious and the service for lunch was again friendly and great.  Overall, whether you're looking for an awesome bar to hang out or a place to enjoy a nice lunch, The Devil's Advocate is your go to place.  They definitely have the right concept, look and hospitality that will make it many people's favourite in the city.

TutbqowBVCblvJHWD1BAyw.text: Of all the fun pubs in Edinburgh, this one really stands out. Amazing food. Amazing drinks. It's close to the touristy mile but still has a very authentic and wonderful neighborhood feel. The whisky cocktails were superb and the food (asparagus app and ox cheek entree) were really fantastic!

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Whisky
Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Asparagus appetizer
Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Ox cheek

6_TF0zPUlmx-clvbUiq23Q.text: Soooooo good great drinks, the food was great I had the lamb, it was to die for, my wife had the veggi meal she said it was orgasmic.... Try it you will love it

xzzff4LXtpWQjsht8r-hRw.text: The atmosphere in this place is awesome. It's a super 'cool' and sort of dark (in a good way) place. We had a corner table so we felt really tucked away and enjoyed that aspect.  This restaurant came up many times from friends, the internet, and forums of what to try when in Edinburgh. I have to say, I don't really get it. Of four of us, nobody loved their meal. Nobody hated it (except me), either. The menu was just too out there and the food we got just wasn't really amazing. The mussels were okay.  The staff was hit and miss. One really nice bartender, another who was rude. Really nice host who sat us, fairly rude server. Personally I'd definitely look elsewhere, unless you're here for all the whisky which in and of itself was also cool too. However, they were out of the first 2 whiskeys we asked for, which was disappointing. I'd skip over this if it were me. Better places elsewhere.

P3nLtmojS80Me__IatkdXw.text: Loved this restaurant, it felt like a little hideaway from the madness that was on Kings Road in August.   I am a lover of craft cocktails and this place had some very interesting, and delicious craft cocktails. One of the cocktails we ordered came with a slice of cheese on the glass attached by a close pin.... pretty cool!  Food was great and there were lighter options if you didn't want to eat heavy.

TOvGEKPT3xRgTceDmqxXiQ.text: OMG! This place is SOOO good. It's my first time in Scotland and found it on Yelp, but let me tell you; I had one of the best meals ever. I went with the waitress recommendation I got the Haggis for starters and braised lamb; both were incredibly delicious. The service was great, also they have a huge selection of whiskey.

545ShopP1fOUyUSYtASOYg.text: I'm guessing they derived their name from the Advocate Close you have to walk into to get here. Not terribly hidden considering how busy it was. First tip - make reservations, they legit had to turn away guests because they were completely full. Even though they need a quick turnaround on tables, the staff is super friendly and I never felt rushed. They are a locally sourcing restaurant so I decided to give it a go.  Food service was fast. I ordered the truffle and hollandaise chips and the fried polenta with poached egg. Both were excellent. Great flavor, well seasoned. The only thing I wished for was my yolk to be a bit more runny than solid, but other than that, I'm really glad I gave this place a try. All in all I was also in and out in 50 minutes with a belly filled with awesome food. Portions were just right too.   If I ever visit Edinburgh again, I'll definitely take another trip to the Devil's Advocate.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Truffle and hollandaise chips and Fried Polenta with poached egg

-cs7uRSCt9DeX8CCF7E1eQ.text: Loved the Potato and Tarragon soup with crusty bread!  We split a fish and chips afterwards, which was also very good. Nice atmosphere off the Royal Mile.  Service upstairs was very friendly and excellent.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

i_x_fWchpTFH8W6OKBx8Kg.text: Kind of tucked away but with a great atmosphere. Food was excellent as well as the staff. Very friendly, great scotch flights

dwyyR06eGIS91XrSTMY-0g.text: I came here three years ago and upon my return for fringe this year made a b-line for Devil's Advocate as soon as my flight landed. Tucked away on Advocate's Close, it's cozy and dark and a great escape from the bustle of the Royal Mile. The food is top-notch and the beer list will satisfy all preferences. The staff is amazing and thoughtful in their recommendations and suggestions (even when I asked the bartender for other restaurant recommendations). My only knock is the cocktails are hit or miss. I had four during my two visits this Fringe: loved two, liked  one, was not impressed with the last.

UT6hBQdNzwb3Aw5x3-yBLQ.text: Delicious, fresh food that changes with the season. I've eaten here many times with friends. Serves both traditional and creative, gourmand dishes. Excellent service. Pleasant patrons and experience.

hxWsHbQAKKPQiJB_zh_3oA.text: A group of 8 of us went to dinner here and we all had an enjoyable time.  My slow and sloe was fantastic, and both the regular and veggie haggis were knockouts.  I had the lobster and it was slightly overcooked, but everyone else enjoyed the meal - the stew was probably the most praised dish at dinner.  We somehow managed to fit in their version of creme brulee at the end and it was a perfect finish to a delicious meal.  The tiramisu was a large portion size so I recommend splitting it, but absolutely save room for it.

Zbhh02N2KBKcCvS6021mkw.text: Over priced, style over substance. I've had better steaks at half the price. Booked a table but ignored when arrived others seated before us. Then put by the Service station and an outside door that the waiter didn't appear to know how to shut.  87 for 2 steaks a bottle of wine and a huge disappointment.

fdPw8rkLJ0xDcFfV_BNSKA.text: Fantastic experience.   The food was delicious (and we tried haggis) and the server was extremely friendly and helpful suggesting scotch to try.  And the interior design - exposed stone walls - make for a wonderful night out.  Can't say enough good things.  Recommend making a reservation in advance.

XVnD6T5xaII7pJZDdTGRlQ.text: My wife and I visited here from Florida. It's a cool, trendy restaurant, with good food and drinks. We ordered the braised lamb and enjoyed it. Recommend checking this place out

Rt6ZlQHmAfIRhDCjfe0MWQ.text: Came to the Devil's advocate while trying a series of cocktail bars. Didn't come for the food, just the drinks and I give it a solid 3/5.   Drinks (3/5) LOVE the fact that all their drinks are taken from Scottish Folklore e.g. the Kelpies which inspired a series of "sea" ish drinks but I wasn't very impressed by any of the drinks I saw on the menu. I suppose I'm kind of biased because I like sweeter drinks, and it's very possible these cocktails were more salty/tangy to go well with the food serve, but there didn't seem to be many options for me. I ended up going with the "Black Dog" which tasted like a strawberry/apple whisky sour (but not as sour!). I also tried a bit of the "Fisherman's Folly," which is surprisingly good! I didn't know what to expect because it had seaweed but it tastes mildly like the ocean; very refreshing. Finally the "Curiosity killed the Captain" which struck me as a lime-y watermelon war head (but maybe not THAT sour). While the drinks are interesting, I didn't fall in love with any of them  Service (3/5) We were greeted (read: carded) immediately as we walked in, handed menus, and ushered to the bar. The bartenders were nice but they weren't interested in making conversation. They made the cocktails you ordered (on the opposite side of the bar...), asked you to pay, then left. Hit the basics, wasn't impressive.  Ambiance (3/5) Nice, small, mood lighting, intimate. The only downsides were 1) there wasn't enough space at the bar and 2) they had a freshly roasted pig leg at the bar which meant the entire place reeked of meat. Not appetizing.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The Black Dog
Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

Jak2pl57GDuwKDdcKt_NJg.text: Came here on a Monday night, busy but had reserved. Amazing food, service and atmosphere. All around ticks all the boxes. Highly recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

BjIuyy4kVtD7ucYyHKZmew.text: A wonderful hidden gem located in an alleyway. All the food we ordered were perfectly seasoned and really creative. It was our first time trying black pudding and were pleasantly surprised by it...The sauce especially was perfect.   The ambiance and decor was also really nice. The exposed stone walls gives it that historic Gothic feel unique to Edinburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

LwZ_mYZ9eq1SWaWbIdG0WA.text: Didnt love this place. Make sure hey don't seat you in the clostrophic bathroom hallway off the bar. Think fake brick wall paper. Ambiance is non-existence.   Ask for a table upstairs which at least will have some natural light. We ordered the rib eye which was very mediocre. The califlower entree was tasty but again not very special. We liked the haggis though.

693Pyrv3WpkrAFF7MFBvjw.text: We decided this restaurant after viewing the reviews on yelp for our first night in Edinburgh. The food is absolutely amazing, the lamb rump is so tender and juicy, the picanca steak with whiskey sauce is palatable. cocktails and dessert drinks are delightful.  Great ambience and  great service!

PXCYVWVc8yrDSAiGwKp_bg.text: Ambience - incredibly cool Service - perfection Drinks - Best I've ever had Food - Killer  This has been the highlight of our Edinburgh trip. My fiance has made a new favorite drink in the black dog. It's unfortunate he will never be able to find one in the states. Our waiter was knowledgeable and helpful. He picked some great drinks for us. I cannot recommend this place enough. Please go here!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

JAtNpFGnt-0rjEACC_lk7Q.text: So this was one of the top rated places to go to so we went to try it out. Well...  1. Try to make reservations. When we went at 5:30 there were already a ton of people waiting for a table.  2. It's loud. Think club loud. Music pumping, I could barely hear my husband or the specials from the waitress.  3. Not baby or handicapped friendly. It's down a little back street with lots of steps.  Did I mention this place was loud.  The food was..ok. The menu had a limited selection of food choices (5 appetizers and 8 entrees to chose from) and everything tasted good but nothing that will blow your mind. Just your wallet and ear drums.   On a positive note, impressive drink menu

rsvGIDUI-_2RV3ksCfjR_Q.text: Away from the bustling streets, we had the corn fritters for starters and they were fantastic.  Our lunch mains were the burger and the picanha that both came with a side of triple cooked fries. The staff were extremely friendly and attentive. If you are looking for a quiet lunch from the busy touristy streets, this place is great.

eE3iS_y9iYUpVJl9F-vqMA.text: One of the best lunches I have had in Edinburgh was from here.  We actually came twice, except the first time we didn't score a table. They told us that a table would be free 2 hours later but that was too late for two hungry men. So the next day, we made a reservation for lunch, which was definitely a good idea.  I was impressed by their beer recommendations, selecting a local blonde on blonde from Leith. And the burger which I ordered medium rare was also perfect, just the right amount of juice, and the bun had enough structural integrity to withstand the juices from the meat. And the chips were quite good too!  I definitely would want to come back if I am back in town.

ZhrvIpuxYo27JxGfCR_UFg.text: Great space, friendly staff but the portions are entirely too small and significantly overpriced. By and large I was unimpressed - not sure why it would be #1 in Edinburgh.

hw0FTLG6K1nBDU30tM9A-g.text: This was a fantastic local place to visit. I was here for a field trip (because the geology in this area is amazing). The students wanted to show us around and we stopped here after an evening of ghost tours. They have both local and imported whiskeys and I was impressed to find they had lighter cocktails if a whiskey neat isn't your style. The tables are intimate and cozy. It's a lovely stop at any time of day. The waitress was insanely knowledgable and clearly has good taste in whiskey. She was able to make successful recommendations to each person's palate. Like I said, great hole in a wall to visit if you're ever in Edinburgh.

EkHu_WnUoVtaRJGoo5ADNQ.text: Tried to get in today with family on a Wednesday around 9:30 and the rude guy that met us said sorry no reservations. Open tables throughout. When I asked him about them he said they were booked and the kitchen was closing soon...I said "what if they don't show"? His response was classic..."well the kitchen is closing anyway" Place seems cool but so many great choices in Edinburgh I would pass! Go for a positive experience!!

fK60b1SKm7l8_E6eTvjk1Q.text: We found the Advocate Close (alley) off of the Royal Mile and eased down the steps with a great view of one of Edinburgh's most iconic structures.  The restaurant has a warm rustic decor.  The hostess was very pleasant and greeted us warmly.  They prepared our table on the second level and seated us very promptly.  The locally crafted beer was very tasty and the fully stocked liquor bar include several gin and whiskey selections. The fish and chips were on point.  The mussels and artisan bread were amazing!  We will definitely be back.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

snqRfqoIaPx9XsEJxz1Bjw.text: The truffle fries are to die for, and the cocktails were really good. Super cool spot.

o73WnOOLCFGTnijlcwXHoA.text: We enjoyed some pre-dinner drinks here. The drinks were good, and both locals and tourists came into the bar area. It's probably better as a dinner venue.  The ambience is nice. Very clean and modern.

xxPGpoo9Cr91rY1Kad8FRw.text: Arrived around 6pm for a drink. No place to sit as empty tables were "reserved".  Bar service was not particularly helpful when asked to recommend a single malt scotch for someone accustomed to blended scotch. Atmosphere not friendly or cozy but rather appears to be more of a restaurant.

6YAhybvJSkGis2PkcNzykg.text: Try the ox cheek! I was skeptical, but decided to go for it. The dish ended up being one of the best I've ever had. If I'm ever back in Edinburgh I'll absolutely be back to The Devil's Advocate for a meal.

8FWf6riUB5aQz4-UPq6TZg.text: Food: 2 stars. Menu lacks cohesion, food lackluster and mostly heavy food. Had haggis, mussels, soup, and salad. Mussels rubbery, soup lukewarm, And how can you mess up chips??? (They can, and did. Soggy, undercooked, sad, and limp.)  Ambiance: 3 stars. Lots of warm candlelight, but tables for two are uncomfortably small.  Service: 1 star. Very brusque, and staff seemed overwhelmed. Plus we were asked to hurry up halfway through our mains because a reservation had arrived and they needed our table. Why even bother to seat us at all?  Drinks: 3 stars. Some interesting cocktails, and had a truly excellent drink. Expensive for what you get, however, and wine list is both average and overpriced.  Experience: 0 stars. Came in with a friend on a late Friday afternoon/early evening. The place was packed, and several drunk people were stumbling around, including one guy who literally pushed a woman out of his way at the bar and spilled her Champagne, no acknowledgement or apology. He was then immediately served and pushed his way back through people, slopping his beer everywhere. Yes, he was an asshole but clearly over served. Crowd in general was mixed but trended toward hipster millennials who nursed drinks and empty glasses, taking constant selfies and talking as loud as humanely possible. I really, really wish I could get that hour and a half of my life back.

8TU2DRDZwSIJz2Lj2X2iuA.text: The server said "welcome back", and I was a little embarrassed, but what the heck, when you find great food while traveling, there is no shame in hitting the same spot 3 days in a row, here is why this place is so good:  1) location. 2 minutes away from the Royal Mile, but miles away from the noise. 2) food. The cheese and meat boards are sublime. With their delicious jams,  pickled veggies, and damn good selection of cheese and meats. The ceviche is solid, but the crispy polenta with wilted greens and poached egg... EPIC! 3) drinks. The cocktail menu is a work of literature. Seriously, someone took great care is developing a consistent storyline based on Greek Theatre. The drinks themselves are a work of art. I kept coming back for the Jazz Hands - a perfect balance of all the ingredients.  4) service. Good people. Knowledgeable and friendly.   Only flaw we experienced was the tiny gin pour in the gin and tonics compared to other spots around town.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Jazz Hands perfection!

1VmKQ7LK9aEuR0cyqXpshQ.text: Thank you, Yelp, once again, for being my local food/fun tour guide while travelling.  Devil's Advocate is a must-do stop in. Delicious, well prepared, well presented pub food -- with an inventive and varied cocktail list to match.  It's a little hard to find unless you know where to look -- keep your eyes peeled for a tiny alleyway, with a deceptively ferocious set of steps leading downwards towards the restaurant (which will be on your left).  Highly recommend any cocktail on the menu -- but if available, be sure to try to Button Up (gin, vermouth, mushroom, mint and moss). Light and refreshing the way the mushroom essence subtly lingers, and it remains perfectly chilled by a frozen stone cube.  The food is delicious too. And it's a spacious, warm venue.  Customer service cannot be beat either. Be sure to ask for Kelvin -- he is a real sweetheart!

NLdk1WmAIZAPLHtnKlE90Q.text: Prices for dinner: between 18 to 30 pounds for an entree.   If you're a tourist seeking traditional Scottish fare, this probably isn't where you want to go. If you just want a delicious dinner and some tasty drinks, then head on over. We came across this place when we spotted their alleyway splitting off from the Royal Mile. I had seen the rave yelp reviews and decided to give it a try. You might not be so lucky trying to get in on a whim though. It does look like their reservations book up. We just happened to get lucky with our walk in, probably because we were going for an early dinner. Point is, get a reservation if you want to grab dinner here.   Food here is amazing. I got the grill of the day, which happened to be lamb for the day I went, and my husband got the picanha (steak). Both were wonderfully tender and cooked perfectly. Each also came with sweet potato, an arugula salad, and grilled portabello mushrooms on the side. Each person also got to choose a sauce on the side. I went from bernaise and my husband got the garlic puree. We only used it on the vegetables though since the meat was perfect on its own.   We also both opted for a pint of beer. I got the blond and he got the stout. He's a craft beer enthusiast and one sip of each seemed to put him in beer heaven.   This meal was the perfect start to our Edinburgh adventures.

h2fHVp4F7hQN6MrdqiSMPA.text: This is a small restaurant in Edinburgh's old town. The restaurant is located along a "close" which is basically a stairway that connects the upper and lower parts of old town Edinburgh. The restaurant is located in an old building and rustically furnished commensurate with the old town period. Their food was excellent. I had the Sauteed wild mushrooms, garlic puree and rosemary croutons starter and the Beetroot tarte Tatin, toasted seeds, goat cheese and heritage tomato salad entree. I also the Chorizo, manchego and chilli chips side. All were delicious. Service was excellent. The restaurant was busy; expect a wait unless you have reservations. I definitely recommend this restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Beetroot main
Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Tabbouleh main
Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Wild mushroom starter

BtzN7b2s8QVAs3TDFZfzDA.text: If you are looking for a fun, off the beaten track pub with a great vibe and Scottish flavor in Edinburgh, this is a great place.  The beer and food was good too.

7gqtxRIYNtqkLy3460DURg.text: BEWARE...CAUTION...so, high expectation met with reality. This is a prime example of what happens when a European restaurant gets high reviews on Yelp and cannot keep up with the demand...of tourist Americans ( which I am). We booked a reservation for 9pm and were seated at around 9:15. Prior to that we had one of their signature cocktails at the bar which were average at best. The place was packed..,with American Tourists. When seating, nothing on the menu was what what described on Yelp. Great, they change their menu but seems it was downgraded to chicken and pork.  Finally, at around 9:30, maybe later, the server came by and simply asked us what we wanted.  No Hi, how are you etc. we to,d her we would start with  a "starter" and have some questions to which she replied, you better hurry, the kitchen is closing. While waiting in the server, I had ordered a beer from the bar called a blonde. It tasted like a wheat, grapefruit, strawberry, rice, cinnamon, insert 10 other flavors, and it was undrinkable. So even before the snotty server came to our table, we were a little miffed. The terrible beer, the average cocktails, the long wait, the extremely loud patrons, the supper small packed in table, we left. Fortunately, the restaurant next door, Angels with Bagpipes, was able to seat us and we had an amazing meal. Through crisis comes opportunity I guess. Very disappointing.  I guess I should have been suspicious to the sign in the door looking for help.

lICEwDGB70n-PzPnA5u7pA.text: Hidden gem, the fish and chips are so tasty. The decor gives the restaurant/bar a cave-like ambience. Will definitely return if I find myself in Edinburgh again... I sincerely hope that I do.

IOKJscRNoDFpEqytaOqEhg.text: Hipster feel.  Dinner was worth coming at 4:30 pm & waiting on, while I enjoyed the Oban 14 yr old whisky as was suggested by Tom the bartender.

oGEVHhw3hgVRLOVABPFWkg.text: This was a fantastic find! The staff showed us wonderful curtesy, exceptional menu and city knowledge, and many laughs! The quirky atmosphere and charming decor is beckoning me back to Edinburgh. Visitor or local, do yourself a favor and visit this alleyway gem!

yZZPxiZf5IhkenAluQysVg.text: Took two tries to get here. First night they were completely booked and we didn't have a reservation. But the second night we finally sat down and it was great. It was great food atmosphere. Warm when it was super cold outside. We were on the second floor but it was an awesome view. The bar was continuously packed and everyone was definitely having a great time.

FcY7zoMBYMSV_8-je6Qgyg.text: We were seated promptly (and luckily) on a Friday night for a later dinner right before the kitchen closed.   Prices were good and the fish of the day we ordered was fantastic! Cooked perfectly, served with a delicious vegetable puree and fresh roasted beets and onions.   We asked the bartender Paul to make us anything and he concocted an absolutely delicious whisky/rum/egg white drink. Service was excellent.   We also loved the atmosphere and decor (entrance off a close, 2 levels, exposed stone and brick, candlelight, Typewritten menus, etc.). Should I ever find myself in Edinburgh again I will be back!

9LaByYtchca6ulJcb8cPQQ.text: Dropped in for a drink and was not disappointed. The bar staff's knowledge and skill was great to see. Great Whiskey , great atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Perfect Old Fashioned.
Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Whiskey Sour.

cuSdTrAyCwmGUGOtnAVMWg.text: When you've had a stressful morning, walked the streets of Edinburgh all day and have some time to waste before your reservation at The Witchery, what do you do? You decide to walk down some random alley (in this case the spectacular Advocates Close) that Edinburgh is littered with, that's what you do. Then, you stumble across a place like the Devil's Advocate and you decide that sitting down for a pre-dinner drink drink is a fantastic idea - and what a fantastic idea it was!  The Devil's Advocate is quite hidden, especially for people who do not frequent Edinburgh half as often as they should. I love the interior all wooden and steel, medieval, kind of thing, it was bustling which was brilliant especially because it was a week night, and their bar is perfectly stocked - with a selection of 200 whiskeys no less. We were seated at a two persons table for drinks. Unfortunately it was on the way to the bathrooms and the kitchen, but fortunately this didn't create too much through traffic.   The girl who was waiting on us was nice enough, she definitely fit the slightly hipster vibe of this place. We didn't see much of her, but she did recommend an amazing lager/IPA hybrid: The Williams Bros. Brewing  Co. Caesar Augustus. Amazing. It went down a treat, and then something incredible happened. For the first time in my life I ate something that in South Africa they call "Corn nibs". A fantastic bar snack, it's essentially dried little bits of sweetcorn with some seasoning. My word, they were amazing (and subsequently I did buy some the next time I went to South Africa), and the only reason that we did get them was because the kitchen was already pretty much closed. A little bit of a downer was that we had to pay for this bar snack - it felt a little like being charged for eating the peanuts that you find on the bar counter.   Their menu looks very inviting, with a lot of focus being put on Scottish produce. Next time I would to see what the upstairs-mezzanine seating area is like. I cannot wait to come back.

C2Vg_1elehADPYLtukMHkg.text: Why are these people harassing me over fb for not liking their establishment. Please stop being cry babies and take your review. Please learn from it and learn how to treat your clients. Enjoy Edinburgh!! Stay away from this shit place!

K2qAG5PQxXUhliSjiVxFwQ.text: This was the first restaurant we went to on our short trip to Edinburgh and no other restaurant in the city afterward measured up. Fantastic location, absolutely gorgeous and cozy, and the food was superb! Staff were so lovely!! Absolutely recommend it!

Hm_k0kghIH4JGKjMkMcrHQ.text: Gotta say that I loved visiting this bar - what a great suggestion by Jenny L and exactly what I fancied after a hard day of toil on the internet! Basically looking like it was carved into the Edinburgh rock, the DA looks very much like a speakeasy in terms of a secret location and from here it was nicely off the beaten path on the Royal mile to avoid shedloads of tourists looking for a quick pint.  We had a quick snack of haggis bonbons - really nice and definitely fulfilling my Haggis needs on this trip, plus a board with serrano ham and manchego cheese, plus fresh bread was the perfect combination for a late afternoon snack.   My pals had cocktails from the extensive list which all sounded pretty exciting but I stuck to the beers as usual. I was very impressed with the Jokers IPA (super hoppy but drinkable at 5%) plus the locally brewed Alba, coming from an ancient Viking recipe - top notch and a very unique brew!   The DA is on my hit list to recommend to anyone who goes to Edinburgh now - very impressed!

ZkC2i8FaIB95ky_wrKBrvQ.text: This place is busy! We came here due to recommendation from almost everyone we spoke to in town. The drink menu is extensive and the two I had were delicious. The outdoor seating area is very nice and relaxed since the restaurant is located in an alley/courtyard area of sorts. The restaurant itself is extremely dark. The service is pretty slow and not too friendly (a symptom of the busy business I guess). The food is pretty good. Everything is slightly under seasoned (a trend we've noticed in this city) but not so much so the food is bland. This is a great place if you're not in a hurry and just want to snack, drink, and relax. Definitely a place worth trying again. Plus its location to our hotel and the Royal Mile makes it very convenient.

5qIRvd_JtBDHuLam2wqkfw.text: Great atmosphere and decor. Went here on a Sunday night, it was a relatively quiet night in the city but this place was still lively. Whiskey and cocktail prices are a bit expensive(4-5 pounds for whiskey and 8-9 for cocktails), but the bartenders really know how to make a drink. Haven't tried the food yet, will have to come back sometime.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. &#39;Mangoes into a Bar&#39; - Mango syrup and whiskey

0KLSgmFxiJUuX1oAaaqHLw.text: The Devil's Advocate is a very nice looking place, the staff seemed friendly and the cauliflower soup was absolutely amazing. My one complaint is it way more expensive than I expected from how portrayed on yelp. For average priced meal that's enough to fill you expect to pay 20 or higher.

WuYWmClyfwQBrMrdEinQpw.text: Once we realized we had to turn down Advocate Close to get there, we found the lunch here delightful. Great cocktails... We sampled memento and afternoon tea in schiedem (vodka, chartreuse, etc). Lunch was simple and well presented.

YsoY70T2zvNkRxQv4eV4rA.text: The atmosphere was amazing. Ideal for a relaxing catchup with friends and the drinks were very good especially the mocktails. The staff were one of the best things about the place because they were super friendly. Highly recommend!!

u4yUa2Cxoq7SB3SW7xu-qw.text: A seriously surprising place. Staff was chatty and professional. Their duck breast was succulent and juicy. The atmosphere was enough to make me stay for more than 3 hours  on my first visit. A mix of bar and resturant, we'll worth a return trip. The barstaffs was amazing. Both surprising with their ability to combine flavours and in matching drinks to food

MBWRcI1NoX8oTZK1HPh64w.text: So well done--gorgeous spot isolated on a close, yet steps from St. Giles. The food was outstanding and the drinks list extensive. I echo comments on slow table service and there is a bit of hipster attitude in the place. But for a mid-afternoon snack it really hit the spot, with very cool ambience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Duck breast, fig, and beet root salad.
Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Pan seared scallops with chorizo.

hjy5TbQwGWppriSEEUNj-w.text: Having just arrived in Edinburgh, we wanted to hit this place (a local friend had highly recommended and confirmed with great reviews on Yelp and Lonely Planet) before attending a comedy show @ 1930 in the west end. A quick taxi drive helped us get there pretty quickly and we were immediately impressed by the cool vibe of the place with indoor/outdoor seating in a multiple levels. I was able to order some incredible mixed drink libations quickly from the bar. As someone failed to show for their reservations, we were seated rather quickly and drinks arrived just as we ordered our dinner. The food was delicious--we had the chickpea dish with squash fritters and the corn fed oven roasted chicken. The service was superb and we were able to make our comedy show. This spot exceeded our expectations and has been a great start to our stay on n Edinburgh.

OHBaNNNDeuVNlzwS0hFOYw.text: Everything here was absolutely wonderful! The food was cooked to perfection, and the beer selection was well up to my date's standards. The location was a bit tough to get to, so if you're unable to walk steps easily, bear that in mind. Other than that, this place is an absolute gem.

uocfKrHLHzd1fHUbqAfanw.text: Hidden away down Advocate's Close, just opposite St Giles' Cathedral on the Royal Mile, is the latest addition to Edinburgh's bustling food and drink scene: The Devil's Advocate. It is by the team from the Bon Vivant of Thistle Street and Stockbridge. Who serve fab food and delectable cocktails in both establishments. The Devils Advocate is in a very atmospheric location and the feeling of intrigue of walking down a misty close is fantastically complemented byt the warm and intriguing view through the glass windows. The building used to be an old pump house and they have retained a lot of the old features keeping it quite industrial and putting in a mezzanine floor - great for people watching! It manages to be spacious but snug at the same time. The cocktails were great and of the same quality as those served at the Bon V you will be glad to know. If you haven't gone you should put it on your list!

photos.caption: Photo of The Devil's Advocate - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

kig9_QfM43P2gzSX4RZ3Bw.text: The Devil's Advocate is a sexy little restaurant squirreled away in the Advocate's Close (right off the Royal Mile).  It's as hip and trendy as any Manhattan restaurant I've been to, and one of the better meals I had in Scotland.    The decor of this place is very chic with exposed brick, soft lighting, and a giant back-lit wall of liquor bottles.  The staff was very friendly and accommodating, as we had a wait for our table we got a few drinks at the well stocked bar.  The crowd here was a little older than I'd have expected in a similar establishment in NYC (people were mostly 40+), but the space was intimate enough that it didn't feel odd.    Now the food.   It was good, very good.  I got a pork dish and my wife got a fish dish and they were both cooked perfectly; my pork dish was well spiced, my wife's fish dish had a broth that didn't overpower the natural flavor of the fish.  Overall it was an excellent meal.  in NYC or Paris I'd give the experience 4/4.5 stars, but for Edinburgh this is top notch, definitely not just a sexy location!  Our final bill was 60 pounds (2 mains + 2 appetizers + 2 drinks), a very reasonable cost.

VFL3V5BNjdFVPgaNpaW3yQ.text: Walking up or down the Advocate's alley you will find the bar/pub style place tagged away from the busy main road called the Royal Mile. The front of the building has massive windows and these additions to the exterior gives this place identity and certainly light.  Inside its warm and the walls thick. Wi-Fi connection a no no, at least for some. The interior presents a modern romantic combination.   I recently attended Yelps 3rd birthday party, which was held on the upper floor. Downstairs is the bar and some tables. I heard the food is excellent. It seems you can hire the upper floor for functions.  We were received very nicely and all of us were handed a glass of excellent prosecco. I think the brand was called WOLF.  Really loved the prosecco. It's really hard to find a good one.  I can recommend this place for singles and couples alike, less for a family outing so.

KITg6ThBpYOTSXoKlYL9UA.text: A Wednesday night in June and they couldn't get two people in until 1.5 hours later. Come on. Pretentious feeling full of yuppie businessmen. Would have liked to eat here but didn't plan ahead 3 days.

3H-dHOAkXQlGuE4r_sS7IA.text: Love this place! Quirky bar just out of sight of the Royal Mile. Not many tables in the bar area with most tables set aside for people eating. That said, it does mean people do share at tables which adds to the sociable vibe.

xrAexBbYmEViiU-xCmhywA.text: I can only rate this place for its venue and drinks, as I have not yet tried the food, but was so impressed with the look of this place I will definitely go back for food soon!! I like this space a lot better then Bon Vivant (same owners), merely because it is a bit bigger and has a very rustic, new hip interior. It is also a neat location off the Royal Mile. The service was excellent and the drink selection is extensive. I was a bit overwhelmed by the amount of whiskey they had, but would recommend this to anyone who is after a nice whiskey. This will certainly be my after dinner whiskey destination. The whole decor of the place is so nice and it felt very warm and cozy despite being quite a bit bigger then it feels. They have some nice, cozy booths you can tuck into or table seating upstairs. A great place to grab a drink and hopefully I can make it to dinner here soon!!

0VoKyv4EORAm6Ig3aFWPwg.text: So loud!  Got indigestion from this pub who's trying to be a restaurant with pricy limited menu. Would not recommend unless you are 21-25 years old.

MnfvQ5OBpxn5zuVjHW2dvA.text: Came here for after dinner drinks (read: scotch).  The whiskey list here is impressive; some 8-10 pages of whiskeys from all over the world.  The atmosphere is very unique, dark and old feeling (in a good way).

bnETNxoq0wkpisuCdE4a2g.text: I had heard of The Devils Advocate but I had never been before, so I was delighted to be on the guest list for Yelps 3rd birthday celebrations which were held there. You can get to the venue on Advocates close from the Royal Mile at the top of the back of Waverley station at the bottom.  It isn't the best signposted so it feels like it is a best kept secret of those in the know.   The inside is over two levels and we had the upstairs mezzanine for the birthday celebrations.  The bar is located on the main floor.   I really like the feel of this place.  The designers have stripped it back to the exposed bricks and added a touch of industrial feel with caged display sections behind the bar.  All the chunky and rustic wooden tables and lighting give it a really warm feeling full of character. The Yelp birthday cake was beautiful, I had the gluten free cake which was the veggie option and it was delicious!  Very more-ish indeed. The staff were top notch.  I would certainly come back here the next time I am out in the Edinburgh old town.

7BnXXj7SAHtCn5NH1v-hrQ.text: Only had time to stop in for a drink.  Very modern looking, really liked the use of limited space.  The did not try to fill it full of tables to limit your ability to move around, it is tight though.  Bare is very industrial looking with large cages holding a large selection of whiskey's with just enough light to show off the wonderful shades of each whiskey.  The wine list and drink menu is diverse covering the customer who knows something to the customer who wants to try something out.  Staff was attentive and kept a very tidy bar and serving areas,  coffee at the ready upstairs for before and after meals.  1st floor both seating looks perfect for privacy and intimate dinning with just the right amount of surrounding atmosphere to keep it a enjoyable night out with just a friend.  Off the Royal Mile down a close next to the real Mary's Close will make this a perfect stop before a tour of the old buried city streets of Edinburgh Scotland.

fHwAdFxpnjtGAdJAqJhNUA.text: The service was not to good, my burguer was over cooked

xjDkyLiokKnKn_AmrnoTrQ.text: Excellent food. Friendly atmosphere. We dropped in looking for lunch for a party of five on Saturday afternoon. Quickly seated and watered. Pork chorizo burgers were delicious and reached the table with ease.   Well worth a little walk of the main drag.

07AIgck46whtPS_O2ooIKw.text: Been to Edinburgh twice. Been to Devils Advocate twice. It is excellent. Great cocktails, fantastic menu and the space is beautiful.

d7ja-tUGyKzFTaXhlWrsPA.text: Fantastic visit here for a late night pint. Didn't get a chance to eat the food but the bar staff was terrific. Friendly and welcoming. I thought the atmosphere and the space was incredible.

vEs2lLjQ6WG-LvfYh7gimQ.text: Burger, chickpea salad, arinccini all amazing, very cool atmosphere, accommodated us last minute!

79Az9_wv1U820hdnkizJoQ.text: Went here to eat a salad for lunch. Loved my beetroot and goat cheese salad with candied walnuts. Friendly service, great atmosphere. The Flat White I had: nothing to write home about.

OHSiqI7zROg1aK56WobeXw.text: Ok, what a find! We were in search of a non-pub meal, but most good restaurants were booked up that evening as we walked the golden mile.  So I Yelped and up came with the Devil's advocate which was close by.  Given we were tired and hungry, we agreed to find it.  Its in one of the side alleys or "close" so not on the beaten path.  Once we stepped in, we were impressed by the beautiful interior of this modern version of the pub (more of a restaurant really).  They had the usual selection of beers and whiskeys to choose from and there was a nice crowd in the bar area.  We quickly found a table for 8, and ordered.  Everyone loved their food! From the burger to the fish and chips, everyone raved about their order (and we are all foodies), so this was a huge hit.  So much so that we wanted to eat there on the return trip through E'burg, but couldnt find time.  Definitely check this place out!!

ONyEwcQYxufaxL1dWpQaUw.text: Awesome whisky collection.  Fish n chips and the fried pasta dish was great.  Ambiance was also great.  Servers were a little stiff but bartender was friendly

JR5Zx4CK7BlhtGpTpZjSHg.text: Delicious food. We are from the US and always looking for those out of the way gems.  This is it.  During festival season on weekends, make sure you have a reservation. The first time we tried without one and it was booked solid for the whole night.

qk7_4g0eMKCJMLKpXji73w.text: To be honest, for the one minute I was inside, it was a great atmosphere and I'm sure the food is great. However, I showed up without a reservation and they told me that they were fully booked on a Sunday. The 1 star rating is because they had plenty of tables open and still wouldn't seat us.

FeY9smOb_XDSV2OKmouU5g.text: Delicious. Pork belly and beef burger and chicken and bulgar with northern African spices. Great ambiance and location.

mJqsAeV6sqREknwNXBDSjQ.text: Great little pub with a modern menu. We had the haggis Bon bons, fantastic. Burger was great, pigeon breast was well prepared, and the hake was great. Kids loved it all. Fun!

v8CffXGFyelmlxDfkW_mhg.text: Cool bar, didnt manage to get a table to eat so would advise to book ahead for a table. Great vibe.

aWUhtkFOMRzkImGUKhvwlQ.text: Loved this place! Went back twice. Enjoyed one of the best salads I have ever had, incredibly fresh and inventive. Excellent atmosphere, beautiful venue, outdoor seating.

ynZGHVn-KGhc_wguIzWVcg.text: I read another review on here who used the term "Dope ambience"...which to me is such an American way to describe this place....but it's not wrong.  This place is down one of the many closes in the city of Edinburgh so turn down this narrow walkway, go down some steps, and then here is the pub nestled among the tall gothic buildings of Edinburgh.  The interior is insane, stone and wood everywhere.  Me and the S.O. were seated right away and given an extensive drink menu.  Their whiskey list is extensive.  I wanted to try all the drinks, they all sounded so good.  The ones I did try were phenomenal.  Our server then chatted us up a bit and recommended other things to do in Edinburgh (since it was our first night there).  Friendly staff?  Check.  Didn't try to food but I imagine that's good too.  So I'm going to take my review above and beyond dope ambience and say that this place is ambient af.  In Edinburgh?  Like booze? Go here.
